body:
This one clearly slipped through the cracks, sorry.

Could you enable debugging (in the UI actions > advanced > GUI > debugging) and then run `syncthing cli debug file <folder-id> <rel-file-path>` on an affected file both on the mac and linux, and post the output here.

Sounds like a similar problem I encountered. Syncing from Linux to Linux where one PC is `send&receive` and the other one is `receive-only`. Both are using the `SyncOwnership` folder config.

Every time I revert the local changes on the receiving PC nearly all files pop up again as local changes.

Maybe that's because of this logic:

```
func unixOwnershipEqual(a, b *UnixData) bool {
	if a == nil && b == nil {
		return true
	}
	if a == nil || b == nil {
		return false
	}
	return a.UID == b.UID && a.GID == b.GID && a.OwnerName == b.OwnerName && a.GroupName == b.GroupName
}
```

In my case the receiver hasn't the same users as it is just a server and it would be sufficient for me if it just stores the `UID` and the `GID`.

The output of `syncthing cli debug file SHARE FILEPATH` seems to support this:

Sender:

```
"unix": {
    "gid": 1234,
    "groupName": "sven",
    "ownerName": "sven",
    "uid": 1234
},
```

Receiver:

```
"unix": {
    "gid": 1234,
    "groupName": "",
    "ownerName": "",
    "uid": 1234
},
```

Because the `ownerName` and `groupName` can't be synchronized the current behavior led to an endless sync loop especially when `receive-only` is set to `send&receive`.

A proposed fix would be:

```
return a.UID == b.UID && a.GID == b.GID
```

Would this be ok?
I think the check should probably be "equal or either side is empty" for the name values...

Wouldn't that fail if the UID or GID is assigned to a different user/group on the target?

I think there is a use-case for both problems:
1. The user wants to make sure the username matches on both systems regardless of the UID.
2. The user wants to make sure the UID matches on both systems because the target system is just used as distributor between machines.

So the better solution would be having a switch to sync either the UID or the username between the hosts. But that sounds like a future thing :-)

> Syncthing records both the numerical UID and GID for a file and the corresponding user and group names, when they are known. When applying ownership Syncthing will first attempt to look up a local user or group with the given name, and if that fails it will fall back to the numerical UID and GID.

You can propose another mechanism, but then that's a separate feature issue I think.

issue.title: lib/protocol: handle empty names in unixOwnershipEqual (fixes #9039)

issue.body:
### Purpose

If syncOwnership is enabled and the remote uses for example a dockerized Syncthing it can't fetch the ownername and groupname of the local instance. Without this patch this led to an endless cycle of detected changes on the remote and failing re-sync attempts.

This patch skips comparing the ownername and groupname if they are empty on one side.

See https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/9039 for details.

### Testing

Proposed by @calmh in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/9039#issuecomment-1870584783 and tested locally in my setup,

Setup PC 1:
  - Syncthing is run in Docker as user `root` and has none of the users configured that synchronize their files

Setup PC 2:
  - this PC has all users locally setup
  - Syncthing runs as `systemd` service as user `syncthing` and has multiple capabilities set to set the correct owner and permissions

Setup PC 3:
  - same as PC 2

Handling:
  - `PC 1` is send & receive and uses just the `UID` and `GID` identifiers to store the files
  - `PC 2` and `PC 3` synchronize their files over `PC 1` but not directly to each other

Outcome:
  - `PC 2` and `PC 3` should send and receive their files with the correct ownership and groups from `PC 1`

body: @calmh Thanks for your help. I hope I understand your proposal correctly and the PR is done right: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/9306

Hey I think I'm having similar issues to backup Android `/sdcard` to Linux backup drive (ext4).

+ Android: 1.27.6 from F-droid, root enabled/granted
Send Only, Send Ownership, Send Extended Attr's.

+ Linux: 1.27.9 from syncthing repo
Receive Only, Ignore permissions, Sync Ownership, Sync Extended Attr's
Running as root systemd service with:
`# /etc/systemd/system/syncthing@root.service.d/override.conf`
`[Service]`
`AmbientCapabilities=CAP_CHOWN CAP_FOWNER`

All the data is synced fine but none of the permissions or ownerships are (not sure if Android uses extended attr's).  On the Linux backup, it shows "Local additions" and the "Revert Local Changes" button appears to work but, within a few seconds, goes back to "Local additions".

This patch would resolve this right? but it's still Unverified/not committed?  Anything I can do to fix my instances?  I found that if I manually use chown/chmod on the Linux backup data, then it becomes synced and number of "Locally Changed Items" decreases.  Thx
